to raise the intake from other taxes. However, it is here important to note that domestic tax hikes are
offs since, at the same time as the spending they fund may provi
benefits, they may also reduce the capacity of households and the private sector to consume and invest,
something that may reduce growth over time and reduced resources for spending in support of human
. It is also worth emphasising that restructuring
amount to changes in the social contract of the society
Combining housing policies with carbon taxation can deliver both housing and
The spatial distribution of households and firms
of development pathways. Patterns of urbanisation, territorial development, and regional integration
ly, choices regarding spatial forms of development have large
Exclusionary mechanisms such as decreasing accessibility and affordability of inner
. Suburbanisation, in turn, is associated with higher transportation
and higher carbon footprints for households
significant positive link between housing prices and energy demand
Reducing emissions from transport in cities through traditional climate policy instruments (e.g., through
rbon tax) is more difficult when inner
urban neighbourhoods are less accessible and less affordable,
because exclusionary mechanisms act as a countervailing force to the rising transportation costs induced
by the climate policy, pushing households outwards
rather than inwards. Said differently, the costs of
city transportation emissions are higher when inner
This suggests that policies making inner
can open up broader opportunities for suburban households to relocate in the face of increasing
transportation costs. This is particularly important for low
a greater portion of their in
come on housing and transportation, and are more likely to be locked into
locations that are distant from their jobs. Making inner
urban neighbourhoods more accessible and more
affordable has the potential to reduce both the social costs
and the economic costs of mitigation policies
as a lower price of carbon is likely
to achieve the same amount of emission reductions since households have more capacities to adjust.
urhoods more accessible and more affordable is a complex endeavour
. At the same time, it is already a policy objective in its own right in many
, independent of the climate mitigation motivation, for a range of social, health and economic

income households often remains out of, or is only emerging in the
